content.description: Stay Left For Numbers climbs the left-most part of the face meandering to the left arete for the overhanging section.  The beginning is kind of on a left-facing corner.
content.protection: Stay Left For Numbers has 2 bolts for anchors.  These are recent additions and the climb used to continue past these anchors, on the easy shattered slab until the dead tree was reached.  They do make for an easy exit and belay.

content.description: Sorcerer's Apprentice climbs the edgy face with a bit of lichen near the top.  It then pops an easy roof. This is an easy and fun climb with good protection.  It is the only all bolted route on this wall. Sorcerer's Apprentice is in the gully on the East of the main wall.
content.protection: Sorcerer's Apprentice has 2 bolts for anchors.  Bring 1 runner to alleviate drag and 3 draws for the route.

climbs.name: Shark Bait
climbs.fa: FRA Doug Heinrich, Pokey Amory, Conrad Anker 1986

content.description: Shark Bait climbs the smooth, water-polished hand crack (2nd from the right) on the right side of the face.  It starts steep but eases up.  Also, it starts in the creek, so traverse over or wait for fall and low runoff.
content.protection: Shark Bait has no fixed anchors, so bring gear and slings.  Medium gear protects this climb.

content.description: OFR works up the left face.  It starts as a smooth but shattered face.  There is an overhang down low, cross this on the left, then follow the crack up to a good ledge. Then traverse right to the west facing wall.  Climb this wall utilizing jugs and horizontal cracks.  Watch for loose rock on the west-facing finish.
content.protection: OFR has no fixed anchors up top, so bring some gear and slings.  This route consists of 2 VERY old pitons (old fixed rings), more for nostalgia then safety.  The gear is sparse on this climb, hence I top-roped it.

content.description: Mister Ed Has Hay climbs the blunt arete in the center of the face.  This is a steep and fun climb.
content.protection: Mister Ed Has Hay has no fixed anchors on it, so bring gear and slings to the top. The guide-book mentions a piton; however, I don't recall seeing it.

content.description: East of Autumn climbs the face near a tree in the gully on the east face of the wall.  It hits a left-trending finger crack, and works this to the ledge.  Here one can finish up on Lone Shark, but the better line is to now follow the 1 bolt to the exit over the mini-roof to the anchors.  This climb has a smooth face followed by the decent but short finger crack.
content.protection: 2 bolts are at the top for the anchors.  Also, there is one bolt (not in the Ruckman guide) right at the roof.  Bring some small gear for the finger crack, and 1 large piece to get to the bolt after the finger crack.

content.description: Lone Shark climbs the last crack on the right.  It has water-polished rock with 3 ledges to break it up.  The exit move is a little weird for a 5.6.  Not too hard, just felt really exposed.  Finger and hand jams are needed for this climb.
content.protection: Bring some gear for the anchors with slings to equalize. Lone Shark protects with large to medium gear.  We used a couple of larger nuts and a couple of hexes.
